title: The Art of Slow Reading in a Fast-Paced World
excerpt: In an age of speed-reading and productivity hacks, we explore the profound benefits of slowing down and savoring every word.
author: Eleanor Vance
content:
Reading is not a race—it's a journey of discovery, reflection, and connection. In our hyper-connected world, where productivity metrics dominate every aspect of our lives, we've somehow convinced ourselves that reading faster is better. Annual reading challenges push us to consume 50, 100, even 200 books per year. Speed-reading courses promise to triple our reading rate. But what if we're missing the point entirely?

Welcome to the counter-cultural movement of slow reading—a deliberate practice of savoring literature rather than devouring it.

## What Is Slow Reading?

Slow reading is the intentional practice of reading at a measured pace, allowing yourself to fully absorb and appreciate the text. It's about depth over breadth, quality over quantity. Unlike skimming or speed-reading, slow reading embraces pauses for reflection, rereading of beautiful passages, and genuine engagement with the author's craft.

Think of it as the literary equivalent of slow food—rejecting the fast-food approach to books in favor of savoring each carefully prepared sentence.

## The Science Behind Slow Reading

Research from cognitive psychology reveals that slow reading significantly improves comprehension and retention. When we read quickly, our brains process words as data points. When we read slowly, we activate different neural pathways that connect the text to our emotions, memories, and existing knowledge.

A 2019 study published in the Journal of Reading Research found that readers who took their time retained 60% more information than speed readers. More importantly, they reported deeper emotional engagement and greater enjoyment of the material.

Neurologically, slow reading allows our brains to create richer mental models. We visualize scenes more vividly, understand character motivations more deeply, and notice subtleties in the author's language that speed readers miss entirely.

## The Benefits of Slow Reading

**Enhanced Comprehension**: When you slow down, you actually understand what you're reading. You catch foreshadowing, appreciate metaphors, and follow complex arguments more easily.

**Deeper Emotional Connection**: Literature's power lies in its ability to make us feel. Rushing through a heartbreaking scene diminishes its impact. Slow reading lets emotions resonate.

**Improved Critical Thinking**: Pausing to consider an author's argument or analyze a character's decision develops analytical skills that extend beyond reading.

**Greater Appreciation for Craft**: You'll notice beautiful sentences you would have skipped—the perfect metaphor, the rhythmic prose, the clever wordplay.

**Stress Reduction**: Slow reading becomes a form of meditation, pulling you into the present moment and away from anxieties.

**Better Retention**: You'll remember books longer and with more detail when you've truly absorbed them.

## How to Practice Slow Reading

**Choose Your Books Wisely**: Select books you genuinely care about. Save beach reads for speed; dedicate slow reading to works that deserve your full attention.

**Create a Reading Sanctuary**: Find a comfortable, quiet space free from distractions. Turn off notifications. Make your reading time sacred.

**Read in Small Portions**: Rather than marathon sessions, read 10-20 pages at a time. This maintains freshness and attention.

**Take Notes**: Underline passages that move you. Write margin notes about your reactions. Keep a reading journal.

**Embrace Rereading**: Don't hesitate to reread paragraphs or even entire chapters. The best books reveal new meanings on second encounters.

**Pause for Reflection**: After each chapter, take a moment to consider what you've read. How do you feel? What surprised you?

**Read Aloud**: Hearing the words engages additional senses and forces a slower pace. Poetry especially benefits from reading aloud.

## Slow Reading in Practice

Start with one book you've been wanting to read deeply. Perhaps it's a classic you've always meant to tackle, a complex novel, or a book of poetry. Commit to reading it slowly—maybe 15 minutes each evening.

As you read, notice the experience. How does it differ from your usual reading? You might find yourself frustrated at first, conditioned as we all are to consume quickly. Push through. The rewards reveal themselves gradually.

You'll start noticing things: the way an author builds atmosphere, the symbolism woven through chapters, the careful construction of sentences. Reading becomes active rather than passive, an art form you're learning to appreciate rather than a task to complete.

## Balancing Slow and Fast Reading

Slow reading doesn't mean abandoning all other books. It's perfectly fine to skim news articles, race through thrillers, or speed-read for information. The key is intentionality—choosing when to savor and when to scan.

Consider adopting a two-track reading system: a slow read for depth and a fast read for breadth. You might slowly work through one literary novel over weeks while simultaneously breezing through lighter fare.

## The Philosophy of Slow Reading

Ultimately, slow reading is about reclaiming reading as a pleasure rather than an achievement. It's recognizing that books aren't just vehicles for information—they're experiences to be savored, artworks to be appreciated, conversations to be had with brilliant minds across time.

In a culture obsessed with optimization and productivity, slow reading is a quiet rebellion. It says that some things in life shouldn't be rushed, that depth matters more than speed, and that the journey is as valuable as the destination.

So the next time you pick up a book, resist the urge to race through it. Slow down. Savor the language. Let the story unfold at its own pace. You'll discover a richer, more rewarding reading life—one page at a time.

title: Top 10 Cozy Mysteries to Curl Up With This Winter
excerpt: From quaint English villages to seaside bakeries, these mysteries are perfect for a rainy afternoon with a cup of tea.
author: Arthur Hastings
content:
Winter is the perfect season for mystery novels—especially the cozy kind. As temperatures drop and darkness comes early, there's nothing quite like curling up under a blanket with a good murder mystery, a cup of tea, and the satisfaction of solving a crime from the comfort of your armchair.

But not all mysteries are created equal. While some readers crave dark psychological thrillers or gritty crime noir, others prefer their murders with a side of charm, wit, and perhaps a recipe or two. Welcome to the world of cozy mysteries.

## What Makes a Mystery 'Cozy'?

Cozy mysteries (sometimes called 'cozies') are a beloved subgenre with specific characteristics that set them apart from traditional crime fiction:

**Small-Town Settings**: Think quaint English villages, coastal Maine towns, or tight-knit communities where everyone knows everyone.

**Amateur Sleuths**: The protagonist is usually not a professional detective—they're bookstore owners, librarians, bakers, knitters, or cat café proprietors who solve crimes as concerned community members.

**Off-Page Violence**: Any murders or violence happen off-screen. You'll read about the discovery of the body, not graphic descriptions of the crime.

**No Profanity or Explicit Content**: Cozies keep things family-friendly in language and scenes.

**Strong Community Focus**: The setting itself becomes a character, with recurring secondary characters creating a sense of home.

**Often Feature Hobbies or Professions**: Many cozy series revolve around specific themes—cooking, crafting, gardening, cats, etc.

**Light Humor**: Despite the murder, there's often wit and warmth throughout.

**Justice Prevails**: Cozies end with the mystery solved and order restored.

## Our Top 10 Cozy Mystery Series

### 1. Miss Marple Series by Agatha Christie

The grandmother of all cozy mysteries deserves the top spot. Miss Jane Marple, the seemingly harmless elderly spinster from St. Mary Mead, uses her understanding of human nature (gained from village gossip) to solve murders that baffle the police. Start with 'The Murder at the Vicarage' and fall in love with Christie's masterful plotting.

**Why Read It**: Christie invented many cozy mystery tropes and her plots remain unmatched in cleverness.

### 2. Three Pines Series by Louise Penny

Set in the fictional village of Three Pines, Quebec, this series follows Chief Inspector Armand Gamache. While Gamache is a professional, the emphasis on community, character development, and the village's charm firmly places these in cozy territory. The books are beautifully written with deep themes alongside the mysteries.

**Why Read It**: Penny's prose is literary, her characters complex, and Three Pines becomes a place you'll long to visit.

### 3. The Cat Who Series by Lilian Jackson Braun

Jim Qwilleran, a journalist, and his two Siamese cats, Koko and Yum Yum, solve mysteries in small-town Michigan. The cats often provide clues (in their own mysterious ways), and the series offers gentle humor and warmth.

**Why Read It**: Perfect for cat lovers who enjoy mysteries with feline 'assistance.'

### 4. Bakeshop Mystery Series by Ellie Alexander

Jules Capshaw returns to her hometown of Ashland, Oregon, to help run the family bakery—and immediately stumbles into a murder mystery. Each book includes mouthwatering bakery recipes.

**Why Read It**: Combining baking with mystery-solving, this series will make you hungry and keep you guessing.

### 5. Witchcraft Mystery Series by Juliet Blackwell

Lily Ivory is a witch who runs a vintage clothing store in San Francisco while solving supernatural mysteries. It adds a paranormal element to the cozy formula while maintaining the genre's warmth.

**Why Read It**: Perfect for readers who want their mysteries with a touch of magic.

### 6. Thursday Murder Club by Richard Osman

Four residents of a retirement village meet weekly to investigate cold cases—until they find themselves investigating a real murder. Recent but already beloved, this British series is witty, poignant, and delightfully clever.

**Why Read It**: Fresh take on the genre with wonderful characters and British humor.

### 7. Knitting Mysteries by Maggie Sefton

Kelly Flynn inherits her aunt's house in Fort Connor, Colorado, and joins the knitting group at the local yarn shop—where murder and knitting patterns intertwine. Each book includes knitting patterns.

**Why Read It**: Ideal for crafters who love mysteries and want patterns to try.

### 8. Booktown Mystery Series by Lorna Barrett

Tricia Miles runs a mystery bookstore in Stoneham, New Hampshire—a town devoted to books. Naturally, real murders complement the fictional ones on her shelves.

**Why Read It**: Meta mystery series perfect for book lovers.

### 9. Flavia de Luce Series by Alan Bradley

Set in 1950s England, eleven-year-old Flavia is an aspiring chemist and amateur detective who solves murders in her village. Despite the young protagonist, these work for adult readers with their sophisticated mysteries and charming voice.

**Why Read It**: Unique protagonist and beautifully evoked post-war England.

### 10. No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency by Alexander McCall Smith

Precious Ramotswe opens Botswana's first female-owned detective agency. While not murders-focused like other cozies, the gentle stories, wonderful characters, and warmth firmly place it in the cozy category.

**Why Read It**: Beautifully written with a unique African setting and philosophy.

## How to Choose Your Next Cozy

Consider your interests beyond mystery. Love cooking? Try a culinary cozy. Passionate about crafts? There are knitting, quilting, and scrapbooking cozies. Cat person? Multiple series feature feline sidekicks.

The setting matters too. Do you prefer British villages, American small towns, or international locations? Historical or contemporary?

## The Appeal of Cozy Mysteries

Why do millions of readers love cozies? In uncertain times, they offer comfort. The violence is contained, the community supportive, justice always served. They're escapism at its finest—transporting you to charming locations where the worst crime gets solved by someone's grandmother or a baker.

Yet good cozies aren't simple or shallow. They offer clever puzzles, character development, and often touch on serious themes—all while maintaining a sense of hope and community.

## Creating Your Perfect Cozy Reading Experience

To truly enjoy a cozy mystery:
- Make yourself a cup of tea (or hot chocolate)
- Find your coziest reading spot
- Eliminate distractions
- Keep a notebook handy to track suspects and clues
- If recipes are included, consider making them
- Don't rush—solve the mystery at the same pace as the protagonist

So this winter, when the world outside is cold and dark, create your own warmth with a cozy mystery. Let these charming amateur sleuths remind you that even in the face of murder, community, kindness, and cleverness prevail. Happy detecting!

title: Why We Still Love Hardcovers in the Digital Age
excerpt: There is something timeless about the weight, the smell, and the texture of a hardcover book that screens simply cannot replicate.
author: Julian Blackthorn
content:
E-readers are convenient, portable, and practical. They hold thousands of books in the space of one. They offer adjustable fonts, built-in dictionaries, and the ability to read in the dark. By every logical measure, they're superior to physical books.

Yet walk into any bookstore, and you'll find shelves packed with hardcover books. Publishers still lead with hardcover releases. Readers still pay premiums for them. Collectors treasure them. Despite decades of digital alternatives, hardcovers not only survive—they thrive.

Why? Because reading is about more than consuming words on a page.

## The Sensory Experience of Hardcovers

Human beings are sensory creatures. We don't just read with our eyes—we read with our entire body. A hardcover book engages multiple senses in ways e-readers cannot:

**Touch**: The texture of a cloth-bound cover, the grain of embossed lettering, the smoothness of the dust jacket, the crisp edges of uncut pages. Even the weight in your hands creates a physical relationship with the book.

**Smell**: That distinctive scent of paper, ink, and binding glue. New books smell different from old ones. Libraries have their own perfume. This olfactory experience triggers memory and emotion in unique ways.

**Sound**: The crack of a new spine (though some collectors cringe), the whisper of turning pages, the satisfying thunk of closing a book. These auditory cues become part of the reading ritual.

**Sight**: Beyond the words, there's visual pleasure in typography, page layout, the color of the paper. Hardcovers often feature beautiful endpapers, ribbon bookmarks, and stunning cover art.

This multi-sensory engagement creates a richer reading experience. A 2018 study from the University of California found that readers reported higher emotional engagement and better recall when reading physical books versus digital texts.

## The Psychology of Ownership

There's something deeply satisfying about owning a physical book that doesn't translate to digital files. Owning a hardcover means:

**Permanence**: A hardcover can last decades, even centuries. Your digital library depends on compatible devices, functioning accounts, and companies staying in business.

**Visibility**: A bookshelf displays your reading life. It's a curated autobiography, visible to you and guests. Digital libraries, no matter how extensive, remain invisible.

**Sharing**: You can lend a hardcover to a friend, leave it in a Little Free Library, or gift it to someone special—complete with your margin notes and memories.

**Inheritance**: Hardcovers become heirlooms. Many people treasure books passed down from parents or grandparents, complete with their annotations and inscriptions.

## The Art of the Hardcover

Publishers invest heavily in hardcover design because they know these books are statements. Consider:

**Cover Art**: From minimalist design to elaborate illustrations, hardcover art is often museum-quality. Designers use embossing, debossing, foil stamping, and special materials to create tactile experiences.

**Typography**: Beautiful hardcovers feature carefully chosen fonts, intentional spacing, and balanced page layouts that enhance readability and aesthetics.

**Special Features**: Ribbon bookmarks, decorative endpapers, maps, illustrations, gilded edges—hardcovers can be as much art object as reading material.

**Limited Editions**: Special hardcover editions feature unique covers, exclusive content, or author signatures that transform books into collectibles.

## The Ritual of Reading Hardcovers

Reading a hardcover is a different experience than scrolling on a screen:

**Intentionality**: You must carve out time and space for a hardcover. Its physicality demands attention in a way that digital books—always competing with notifications—cannot.

**Progress Tracking**: The physical act of moving through a book—feeling it grow lighter in your left hand, heavier in your right—creates a tangible sense of progress and accomplishment.

**No Distractions**: A hardcover can't notify you of emails, texts, or social media. It offers single-focus refuge in our multi-tasking world.

**Reading Posture**: Hardcovers encourage better posture and positioning than scrolling on devices, reducing eye strain and creating healthier reading habits.

## Building a Personal Library

A collection of hardcovers is more than books—it's a curated space that reflects identity:

**Self-Expression**: Your bookshelf tells a story about your interests, values, and intellectual journey.

**Inspiration**: Seeing your unread books motivates future reading. Studies show visible reminders increase goal completion.

**Comfort**: Many readers find comfort surrounded by their books. A personal library creates a sanctuary.

**Conversation Starters**: Guest notice bookshelves. Books become bridge to connections and conversations.

## Investment Value

While most people don't buy hardcovers as investments, they do retain and sometimes gain value:

**First Editions**: Particularly from acclaimed authors, can appreciate significantly.

**Signed Copies**: Author signatures make books unique and valuable.

**Out-of-Print Titles**: Become harder to find and more valuable over time.

**Condition**: Well-maintained hardcovers hold value while e-books can become inaccessible.

## The Environmental Question

Some argue e-readers are more environmental. The reality is complex:

E-readers require rare earth metals, energy-intensive manufacturing, and create e-waste. They typically need replacement every few years. A 2020 environmental study found you'd need to read 100+ books on an e-reader to offset its production impact.

Hardcovers use paper (increasingly from sustainable sources), can last for generations, and are completely recyclable. Used hardcovers reduce environmental impact further.

## Digital and Physical: Not Either/Or

Many devoted readers embrace both forms:

**E-readers for**: Travel, trying new genres, library books, reference materials, books you may not keep.

**Hardcovers for**: Favorite authors, books you want to keep, gifts, displaying, rereading, collecting.

It's not about rejecting technology—it's about recognizing that different reading experiences serve different needs.

## The Future of Hardcovers

Despite predictions of their demise, hardcover sales remain strong. In fact, during the pandemic, physical book sales surged. Why?

Because in an increasingly digital world, people crave tangible objects. Screen fatigue is real. The desire for permanence in an ephemeral age is powerful. Books satisfy these needs.

Publishers understand this. They're investing in better design, higher quality materials, and creative formats. The books being produced now are more beautiful than ever.

## The Romance of Hardcovers

Ultimately, loving hardcovers is about romance—not in the genre sense, but in choosing beauty, tactility, and ritual over pure efficiency.

It's deciding that the crack of a spine, the scent of paper, and the weight of words made physical matters. It's valuing the journey over speed, experience over convenience.

In a world increasingly lived through screens, hardcover books ground us in the physical. They remind us that some pleasures require patience, presence, and the willingness to embrace beautiful inefficiency.

So yes, e-readers have their place. But hardcovers? They hold a place in our hearts, on our shelves, and in our reading lives that no screen will ever replace.

Because some things—like the perfect book, in your hands, on a quiet evening—don't need to be improved. They just need to be savored.

title: How to Start Your Own Local Book Club: A Complete Guide
excerpt: A step-by-step guide to gathering your friends, picking the right books, and fostering meaningful discussions.
author: Elizabeth Bennet
content:
Community is at the heart of reading. While turning pages is often a solitary activity, discussing those pages with others transforms the experience into something richer, deeper, and infinitely more rewarding. A good book club becomes more than a reading group—it becomes a community of friends, a intellectual salon, and a highlight of the month.

Starting a book club might seem daunting, but with the right approach, you can create a thriving literary community that lasts for years. Here's your complete guide.

## Step 1: Define Your Vision

Before recruiting members, clarify what kind of book club you want:

**Format**: Will you meet monthly or bi-weekly? In-person or virtually? What day and time works best?

**Size**: Ideal size is 6-12 people. Fewer than 6 might feel sparse if people cancel; more than 12 makes deep discussion difficult.

**Focus**: General fiction? Specific genres? Classics? New releases? Non-fiction? Mixed bag?

**Commitment Level**: Casual and flexible, or structured with mandatory attendance?

**Additional Elements**: Just discussion, or will you include snacks, themed activities, author events?

## Step 2: Find Your Members

Locate people who genuinely love reading and discussion:

**Start with People You Know**: Friends, colleagues, neighbors who are readers.

**Use Social Media**: Post in local community groups, Nextdoor, or library pages.

**Library Bulletin Boards**: Many libraries allow book club postings.

**Local Bookstores**: Ask if you can post a sign or if they know interested readers.

**Word of Mouth**: Tell everyone. Readers know other readers.

**Meetup.com**: Create a group and see who joins.

**Friend-of-Friend**: Ask potential members if they know anyone else who'd be interested.

**What to Look For**: Seek people who are reliable, respectful of others' opinions, and willing to read outside their comfort zones occasionally.

## Step 3: Choose Your Meeting Space

**Home Hosting (Rotating)**: Most intimate option. Members take turns hosting. Consider space limitations and comfort levels.

**Coffee Shop or Café**: Public, accessible, no cleanup. Can be noisy; check if they're okay with groups staying a while.

**Library Meeting Room**: Often free, quiet, neutral territory. Book on schedule.

**Bookstore**: Some bookstores offer meeting spaces, creating built-in book access.

**Virtual (Zoom, etc.)**: Most flexible for scheduling and geography. Works well for busy or distant members.

**Hybrid**: Combine in-person with virtual attendance for maximum flexibility.

## Step 4: Establish Ground Rules

Successful book clubs need clear guidelines:

**Attendance Expectations**: What happens if you can't make it? Should you notify someone?

**Book Completion**: Is it okay to come having not finished? (Some clubs require finish, others are flexible)

**Discussion Etiquette**: 
- Everyone gets to speak
- No interrupting
- Respectful disagreement
- No spoilers for unfinished sections
- Stay on topic (somewhat—tangents happen!)

**Book Selection Process**: Rotation? Voting? Theme months?

**Time Management**: Start and end times matter, especially on weeknights.

**Bringing Guests**: Policy on bringing friends occasionally?

**Social Media**: Are you posting about your club? Are meetings private discussions?

## Step 5: Select Books Strategically

Book selection can make or break a group:

**Variety is Key**: Mix genres, lengths, styles, and time periods. Don't let one person dominate selections.

**Rotation System**: Each meeting, a different person selects the next book. This ensures variety and buy-in.

**Avoid Books Members Have Read**: Check before finalizing. Reading together creates shared experience.

**Consider Length and Difficulty**: Mix challenging literary fiction with lighter reads. Vary lengths—sandwich a 600-page tome between two shorter books.

**Availability**: Choose books easy to obtain through libraries, bookstores, or e-books. Consider cost.

**Discussion Potential**: Some books are wonderful but don't generate much discussion. Look for books with:
- Interesting characters and relationships
- Moral dilemmas or controversial themes
- Unique settings or time periods
- Multiple layers of meaning
- Complex plots or structures

**Create a Reading List**: Plan 3-6 months ahead so members can find books and schedule reading time.

**Theme Months**: Occasionally assign themes (banned books, debut authors, books set in summer, etc.) for variety.

## Step 6: Facilitate Great Discussions

The discussion leader (rotating monthly works well) should:

**Prepare Discussion Questions**: Have 8-10 questions ready. Mix surface-level and deep questions:
- What did you think overall?
- Which character did you identify with most? Why?
- What themes stood out?
- How did the ending make you feel?
- If you could ask the author one question, what would it be?
- How does this compare to other books we've read?

**Start Strong**: Begin with a straightforward question to get everyone talking.

**Encourage Participation**: Gently draw out quiet members: "Sarah, I'd love to hear your thoughts on...";

**Manage Dominant Speakers**: Politely redirect: "That's interesting, John. Let's hear from others..."

**Allow Tangents (Some)**: Book discussions naturally veer into personal stories, current events, related topics. Some deviation enriches discussion—just redirect if it goes too far.

**Embrace Disagreement**: Different interpretations make for rich discussion. Facilitate respectful debate.

**Don't Force Completion**: Allow for "I didn't finish but..." contributions without judgment.

**Time Management**: Keep discussion focused but not rushed. Save casual chatting for after if needed.

## Step 7: Enhance the Experience

**Themed Refreshments**: Serve food/drinks related to book settings or cultures.

**Author Events**: Occasionally read books by local authors and invite them to join discussion (virtual or in-person).

**Movie Tie-Ins**: If a book club selection has a movie adaptation, watch it together after discussion.

**Book-Related Activities**: For historical fiction, research the time period. For memoirs, look up additional information about the person.

**Reading Challenges**: Create internal challenges: read authors from different countries, diverse voices month, etc.

**Anniversary Celebrations**: Celebrate milestones (one year, 50 books, etc.) with special gatherings.

**Gifts and Swaps**: Do occasional book swaps or holiday book exchanges.

## Step 8: Handle Common Challenges

**Declining Attendance**: Check in individually. Adjust frequency or format if needed. Consider whether the club has run its course.

**Personality Conflicts**: Address privately and kindly. Sometimes people aren't good fits.

**Book Selection Disputes**: Go back to your selection system. Maybe vote if there's controversy.

**Unbalanced Discussions**: Some members dominate, others never speak. Implement Speaking Time or similar structure.

**Life Changes**: Members move, have babies, change jobs. Be flexible and welcome new members to replace those who leave.

## Step 9: Virtual Book Club Tips

If meeting online:

**Choose the Right Platform**: Zoom works well for seeing everyone. Google Meet, Webex, or Teams also work.

**Test Technology**: Do a trial run before your first meeting.

**Establish Speaking Order**: Raise hands feature or speaking rotation prevents talking over each other.

**Keep Cameras On**: Seeing faces creates connection.

**Record Discussions**: (With permission) Allow absent members to catch up.

**Share Resources**: Use shared docs for book lists, questions, and notes.

## Step 10: Make It Last

**Consistency**: Meet regularly on the same schedule.

**Communication**: Create a group chat or email thread for between-meeting discussion.

**Flexibility**: Adapt as needed. Listen to member feedback.

**Celebrate**: Acknowledge milestones and achievements.

**Remember the Purpose**: It's about books, yes, but also about community, connection, and friendship.

## The Magic of Book Clubs

A great book club becomes more than a reading group. It becomes a place where:
- Quiet voices find confidence to speak
- Different perspectives expand understanding
- Friendships deepen through shared stories
- Challenging books become accessible through collective wisdom
- Reading transforms from solitary to social

Your book club might start small, might stumble at first, might evolve in unexpected ways. That's exactly right. The best book clubs aren't perfect—they're authentic communities of readers who want to share stories, ideas, and connection.

So gather some friends, choose a book, pick a date, and start your book club. You're not just creating a reading group—you're building a community. And that, like the best books, is something truly special.

title: In Conversation with Debut Author Sarah J. Maas: On Writing, Inspiration, and Building Worlds
excerpt: We sat down with the rising star to discuss her writing process, her inspirations, and what's next for her characters.
author: Rory Gilmore
content:
Writing a first novel is daunting. Publishing it? Terrifying. Watching it become a phenomenon? Surreal. Yet debut author Sarah J. Maas navigates all three with remarkable grace, humor, and humility.

Her breakout fantasy novel captivated readers worldwide with its intricate world-building, complex characters, and prose that shifts seamlessly between lyrical beauty and gut-punching emotion. We sat down with Sarah to discuss her journey from aspiring novelist to published author, and what lies ahead.

## The Beginning: From Reader to Writer

**You've said you're a reader first, writer second. How did that reader identity shape your writing?**

SJ: I think being a voracious reader is the best writing education you can get. I didn't study creative writing academically—I studied business—but I've read thousands of books. You absorb storytelling structure, character development, and prose rhythm through reading.

The books I loved most as a teen—epic fantasies with strong female characters, complex magic systems, romantic tension—those became the blueprint for what I wanted to write. I wanted to create the kind of book that would have meant everything to teenage me.

**At what point did you decide to actually write this book?**

SJ: I'd been writing seriously since I was sixteen, but this particular story came to me when I was nineteen. I was in a mythology class, and we were discussing various underworld myths. I suddenly had this image of a young woman caught between two worlds, with impossible choices and no good options.

I went home that night and wrote 5,000 words. I didn't outline or plan—I just followed that character and saw where she led me.

## The Writing Process: Discipline Meets Chaos

**Walk us through your typical writing day.**

SJ: *laughs* There's no typical day, but I'll give you the ideal version. I wake up early—I'm most creative in the morning—and I write for two to three hours before I do anything else. No email, no social media. Just me, coffee, and the manuscript.

I aim for 2,000 words on writing days. Some days I hit 5,000. Some days I write 500 words, delete 400, and call it progress. The key is showing up. Inspiration is wonderful, but discipline gets books written.

**Do you outline extensively or discover as you write?**

SJ: I'm somewhere in between. I know the major plot points—the beginning, the end, and maybe three crucial scenes in the middle. But how I get there? That's discovery.

My characters surprise me constantly. I'll plan for them to do one thing, and they absolutely refuse. I've learned to listen to them. Usually, they're right.

**How do you handle writer's block?**

SJ: I don't call it writer's block—I call it story problem. Something's broken in the narrative, and my subconscious knows it even if I don't consciously understand yet.

When I hit those walls, I step back. I go for a walk, take a shower, do dishes—anything that lets my mind wander. Often, the solution appears when I'm not actively hunting for it.

If that doesn't work, I skip ahead to a scene I'm excited about. I can always come back and fix the difficult part later.

## World-Building: Creating Places That Feel Real

**Your world feels incredibly lived-in. How do you approach world-building?**

SJ: I'm a bit obsessive about it, honestly. I have notebooks full of information readers will never see—histories, languages, daily customs, governmental structures, economic systems.

But here's the key: I don't dump all that information into the story. World-building should be the foundation, not the house. Readers should feel the depth without being overwhelmed by it.

I learned this from Tolkien and Le Guin. They created rich worlds but revealed details organically, through the story and characters. The world serves the narrative, not the other way around.

**How do you balance familiar fantasy tropes with original elements?**

SJ: Tropes exist because they work. Reader recognize and enjoy them. The trick is adding your unique spin.

I wanted to write a chosen one story, but with a protagonist who's messy, makes terrible decisions, and isn't special because of magic—she's special because of her choices.

Romance is another example. I love a good enemies-to-lovers arc, but I wanted to complicate it with trauma, power dynamics, and genuine moral disagreements. Make the familiar feel fresh.

## Characters: Writing People, Not Archetypes

**Your protagonist is refreshingly flawed. Was that intentional?**

SJ: Absolutely. I'm tired of perfect heroines who are brave, beautiful, and make all the right choices. Real people are complicated. They're brave and terrified. They make noble choices and petty ones. They save the world and screw up their personal relationships.

I wanted my protagonist to feel real. That means showing her strengths and weaknesses, her growth and her mistakes. Some readers find her frustrating. Good. Real people are sometimes frustrating.

**How do you make side characters memorable?**

SJ: I write full backstories for every named character, even if most of it never makes it to the page. When I know their history, motivations, and secrets, they become three-dimensional.

Also, I give them lives outside the protagonist's story. They have their own goals, relationships, and arcs. They're not just there to support the main character—they're living their own lives.

## The Hard Part: Rejection and Revision

**You famously faced numerous rejections before getting published. How did you handle that?**

SJ: Not well at first. *laughs* The first rejections devastated me. I cried, questioned everything, almost quit.

But then I realized—every published author has rejection stories. J.K. Rowling. Stephen King. They all got rejected repeatedly. Rejection is part of the process.

I started viewing rejections differently. Each one meant I was brave enough to put my work out there. Each one was practice for the eventual yes. And the constructive rejections—where agents or editors explained why it wasn't right—those helped me improve.

**How many times did you revise this book?**

SJ: I lost count after fifteen drafts. Major revisions, minor tweaks, cuts, additions—I reworked this manuscript for three years.

My first draft was 200,000 words. Way too long. Learning to cut was painful but necessary. Kill your darlings and all that.

But revision is where good books become great. First drafts are for discovery. Revision is for craft.

## Inspiration: Where Stories Come From

**What inspired this particular story?**

SJ: Honestly? Everything. Mythology—Greek, Norse, Celtic, Egyptian. History—particularly the Wars of the Roses and various revolutions. Other books—too many to count. My own experiences with loss, love, identity.

It's all a remix. I absorbed influences and transformed them into something new. That's what all writers do.

**Do you have writing traditions or superstitions?**

SJ: I always write to music. I create playlists for each book, each character, even specific scenes. Music bypasses my logical brain and taps into emotion.

I also have a specific coffee mug I use only for writing. Is it magic? Probably not. Does it feel magic? Absolutely.

## Advice for Aspiring Writers

**What do you wish you'd known when you started?**

SJ: That first drafts are supposed to be terrible. I spent years thinking good writers produced perfect prose on the first try. They don't. Everyone writes garbage first drafts. Give yourself permission to write badly.

Also, comparison is deadly. I wasted so much time comparing my unfinished first draft to other authors' published, polished works. You're comparing apples to unicorns.

**What's your number one piece of advice?**

SJ: Finish the book. So many aspiring writers have half-finished novels. They start strong, hit the messy middle, get discouraged, and start something new.

Finish messy. Finish badly. Just finish. You can't revise what doesn't exist. You need to prove to yourself that you can complete a novel before worrying about whether it's good enough.

## Looking Ahead

**What's next for you?**

SJ: The sequel is in progress—well past first draft, deep in revisions. I'm also developing a companion series set in the same world but different time period.

And I'm slowly planning something completely different—contemporary fantasy, much smaller scale, more intimate. After epic fantasy, I want to try something quieter.

**How has success changed your writing?**

SJ: The pressure is real. First book, you write for yourself. Second book, you're aware people are waiting, judging, comparing. It can be paralyzing.

But I try to remember why I started writing: love of story. If I can keep that central—writing the books I want to read—I'll be okay.

## Final Thoughts

**What do you hope readers take from your books?**

SJ: Honestly? I hope they escape for a while. I hope they feel seen in my characters' struggles. I hope they close the book feeling something—anything.

Books saved my life as a teenager. They gave me hope, showed me possibilities, helped me survive hard times. If my books can do that for even one reader, I've succeeded.

At the end of the day, I'm just a reader who learned to write. I'm living my dream, and I'm grateful every single day that people want to read these stories that live in my head.

**Thank you, Sarah.**

SJ: Thank you. Back to writing now—these characters won't torture themselves! *laughs*
